question:
(a) What is Commerce?

(b) State and explain the importance of any five ancillary services to trade.
answer:
(a) Commerce;n wants. Commerce is trade and aids to trade e.g advertising , insurance, banking, transportation and warehousing.

(b) Importance of five aids to trade are:

(i) Banking: Banks aids commerce by making funds available to traders and other business establishment in the form of loans and overdrafts

(ii) Transport: This provides the means of carrying both raw materials and finished goods to where they are needed

(iii) Advertising: Advertising ensures that the goods are brought to the awareness of the consumer

(iv) Warehousing: This ensures the storage of goods till they are wanted

(v) Insurance: This enables the trader to obtain compensation in the event of any loss arising from fire, accident etc.

(vi) Communication: This ensures the exchange of information from one place to another.

question:
(a) Messrs Ola and Musa are both merchants. Ola trades on cash basis only while Musa allows credit. Give four reasons each why Ola insists on cash payment and Musa allows credit sales.

(b) Distinguish between cash discount and trade discount.
answer:
(a) Reasons why Musa allows credit sales are:

(i) Musa allows credit sales to make it possible for customers to have immediate possession of goods they need, even if they do not pay once.

(ii) He allows credit sales in order to increase his sales

(iii) Credit sales brings higher profit.

(iv) The increased sales which results from granting credit reduces the risk of holding stock.

Reasons why Ola insists on Cash payment are:

(i) Ola insists on cash payment in order to reduce the risk of non-payment.

(ii) Credit sales involve a lot of book keeping.

(iii) To avoid-additional expenses resulting from court action against a defaulter.

(iv) The capital of the business will not be eroded as a result of continuous credit sales.

(b) Cash discount; is the allowance given to the buyer by the seller to encourage prompt payment. Cash discount terms are stated on the invoice that accompanies the goods. Trade discount is the allowance off price list. It is a deduction in the standard price or catalogue price of goods on sale to encourage quantity purchase or to provide for the retailer's gross profit margin. It is quoted as a percentage deduction from the retail price.

question:
(a) Explain the meaning of working capital and state its importance.

(b) Outline any seven factors which might affect the rate of turnover.
answer:
(a) Working capital: The different transactions of a business makes it mandatory to have ready and available funds for its daily transaction. Therefore, the capital for the running of a business is called working capital. It is the excess of current assets over current liabilities. Working capital = Current assets less Current liabilities.

Importance of working capital are:

(i) It provides the basis for profit making.

(ii) It is used for financing the daily transactions of a business.

(iii) Working capital is a test of the solvency of a business.

(iv) The life of a firm depends on the working capital because business activities are carried out from it.

(v) It serves as a yard stick for investors.

(vi) Indicates that business is not being financed by supplier. vii. Serves as a check against tying down too much money for current assets.

(b) Factors that might affect the rate of turnover are:

(i) Effective advertising and sales promotion will stimulate demand and hence turnover.

(ii) Offer of credit facilities can induce customers to buy.

(iii) The price of the goods will determine the demand, low price will increase demand.

(iv) Type of goods is another factor.

(v) The reputation and goodwill of the trader plays a part in enhancing turnover.

(vi) Another factor is the regularity in supply of goods sold.

(vii) The location of the store i.e urban or remote centres.

(viii)The number of competitors in the market.

question:
(a) What is a bonded warehouse?

(b)State four ways in which a bonded warehouse may be useful in international trade.
answer:
(a) Bonded warehouse; is a warehouse used for storing goods on which customs duty is yet to be paid. The custom will issue a release warrant authorizing the release of the goods once the duty have been paid.

Uses of bonded warehouse in international trade are:

(i) Bonded warehouse provides the importer an opportunity to sell the imported goods while in bond.

(ii) The importer can also complete some processing on the goods while in bond e.g packaging.

(iii) It facilitates international trade transactions.

(vi) Safety of goods imported is also guaranteed.

(v) Effective check on the goods in bond can be made by the Customs Authority as to ascertaining import duties on contraband goods etc.

question:
(a) Give any five advantages of advertising.

(b) What are five distinctive merits of television as a medium of advertising.
answer:
(a) Advantages of Advertising are:

(i) It creates employment opportunity for all who work in advertising firms.

(ii) It arouses the interest of the consumers in a particular product.

(iii) It gives vital information about the products.

(iv) It affords the producer the opportunity of explaining the use and features of a product.

v. Mass media gain through increase in their revenue from advertisers.

(vi) It encourages healthy competition among firms which leads to increase in quality of goods and services.

(vii) Advertising leads to mass production as a result of increase in demand.

(viii) It creates awareness about the existence of a new product.

(b) Merits of Television are:

(i) The consumers are able to see the actual shape, form and colour of the product.

(ii) It appeals to two senses - sight and hearing.

(iii) The techniques used capture the attention of everybody

(iv)The consumers can also see the actual method of using the product.

(v) It permits the demonstration of the products advertised for everybody to see.

question:
Distinguish between the following:

(a) Broker and Jobber.

(b) Gross profit and net profit

(c) Fixed capital and liquid capital.

(d) Factors and del credere agents.

(e) F. 0. B. and C. I. F.
answer:
(a) Broker; is an agent who links the principal with the third parties. He does not have possession of the goods and he cannot sell in his own name. He receives commission, termed brokerage while Jobber is an agent that buys and sells on his own behalf for a profit. The jobber normally deals in stocks and shares. He will buy at a price and hopes to sell at a higher price. His profit is called jobber's turn.

(b) The Gross profit; is the excess of the selling price over the cost of goods. This is the overall profit before the deduction of expenses. This is ascertained in the trading account while Net profit is the profit arrived at after deducting expenses from the gross profit. This is the actual profit of the business. This is ascertained in the profit and loss account

(c) Fixed capital; are the durable assets of a business that can last for a long period of time. These are motor van, machinery, land and building etc. which are used for further production while Liquid capital are the current assets of a business. They are used to meet the day-to-day financial needs of the business. e.g. stock of goods, cash.

(d) A factor; is defined as an agent who is employed to sell goods delivered to him by the principal for compensation. He has possession of the goods and can sell the goods in his own name while Del credere Agent is one who usually in return for extra renumeration, undertakes to indemnify his principal against any loss arising from the failure of persons with whom he contracts on his principal behalf to carry out their parts of the contract. He receives higher commission than other agents.

(e) FOB (Free on board); is a price quotation which covers all costs up to the ship including the cost of loading the goods in to the ship. The buyer is responsible for the cost of unloading the goods while CIF (Cost Insurance and freight) means that the price quoted includes the cost of the goods. the freight and insurance to the port of destination. The buyer is responsible for other charges thereafter.

question:
(a) What is consumerism?

(b) Give three reasons why consumers need protection.

(c) State any five measures taken by government or associations to protect consumers in Nigeria.
answer:
(a) Consumerism; is the view of having the interest of consumers in production and distribution of goods and services. Consumers need to be protected in the course of consuming goods and services produced.The consumer is "the king". A recognition of the principles that consumer is sovereign e.g fixing price that suits consumer, producing goods that consumer likes.

(b) Reasons for Consumer protection are:

(i) To reduce exploitation of the consumers by the manufacturer in the form of high prices.

(ii)To ensure the supply of quality goods.

(iii) Consumers need protection to ensure that goods offered for sale do not contain dangerous chemicals or damaging side effect.

(iv)To avoid use of incorrect weight and measured of goods.

(v) Consumers are protected against false credit facilities.

(vi) They should be protected against misleading advertisement.

(vii)To ensure regular supply of goods and services.

(c) Measures taken by government or association to protect consumers in Nigeria are:

(i) The ministry of health was mandated to set eagle eye on the manufactures and sales of dangerous food items and drugs.

(ii) Trade associations are also set up to reduce exploitation by maintaining uniform prices of goods.

(iii) The Price Control Board was set up by the government and charged with the responsibility of regulating prices.

(iv) The standards organisation was created to organise, tests and do everything necessary to ensure compliance with approved standards.

(v) The prices and income board was set up by the government to regulate reward for labour, i.e wages and salaries.

question:
(a) What is meant by the term insurable risk?

(b) Explain any four circumstances when an insured may not be indemnified.
answer:
(a) Insurable risks; are those in which the Insurance company is able to estimate the likely future losses. The risks can be estimated and calculated, e.g. motor vehicle insurance.

(b) Circumstances when an insured may not be indemnified are:

(i) An insured may not be indemnified if he has no insurable interest in the object insured i.e. he will not be compensated for insuring a friend's car.

(ii) If an insured fails to adhere to the principle of utmost good faith. If there is deceit in disclosing all materials facts that might influence the insurer whether to accept or not to accept.

(iii) If an insured tries to make profit from insurance, he may not be indemnified. The principle of contribution prevents an insured from making profit from insurance.

(iv) An insured may not be indemnified if the cause of the event insured against was not the risk insured against. For insurer to indemnify the insured, he must make sure that the immediate or proximate cause of the event insured against was the risk insured against.

question: Describe any five advantages of the Stock Exchange Market.
answer:
Advantages of the Stock Exchange Market are:

(i) The stock exchange makes it possible for investments to be converted into cash.

(ii) Being specialist in the stock market, members of the Stock Exchange are able to advise investors on which securities to buy.

(iii)The Stock Exchange market helps to raise capital needed for their business operations.

(iv) The Prices quoted at the market serve as a yard stick to measure the goodwill of their companies.

(v) It enables the government to raise the capital they require for development.

(vi) It provides a financial market for those wishing to invest their money in company shares.

(vii) The values of shares, stocks, bond, gilt edged securities are determined in the market.
